Getting started

AMATEUR is a collection of tools to analyze snapshots from cosmological simulations performed with GADGET-2. It uses AHFstep from AMIGA to isolate halos and subhalos, Halo to extract properties for custom halos out of only one particle type, and stores all output in HDF5 or plain text files.

Compilation

AMATEUR needs following non-standard packages to be installed on the system:

  • GSL - the GNU scientific library. This open-source package can be obtained at http://www.gnu.org/software/gsl.
  • HDF5 - the Hierarchical Data Format. This library has been developed by NCSA and can be obtained at http://hdf.ncsa.uiuc.edu/HDF5 .
  • FFTW - the Fastest Fourier Transform in the West. This open-source package can be obtained at http://www.fftw.org.
  • AMIGA - the halo finder developed by A. Knebe.

The provided makefile is compatible with GNU-make, i.e. typing make should build the executable amateur. If your site does not have GNU-make, get it, or write your own Makefile.

Running the code

AMATEUR is invoked using the following syntax

./amateur ID -{xamszht} or ./amateur ID

where ID describes a snapshot given in Global and xamszt invoke the different commands

  • x - Extract snapshot data into a HDF5 file
  • a - Analyze the given snapshot using AHFstep from AMIGA
  • o - wrap AHF output files for use in MATLAB
  • m - Run MergerTree
  • s - Match subhalos with their hosthalo.
  • z - Analyze the given snapshot using Halo
  • t - Compute the tidal field of the mass distribution
  • h - Run HaloTracker from AMIGA. This is a planned feature and not implemented yet.

If only the snapshot ID is given as input parameter to amateur, it will run through the commands in the order listed above.
